messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 51 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Enhancing reinforcement learning by a finite reward response filter with a case study in intelligent structural control

Paper Abstract: Abstract In many reinforcement learning (RL) problems, it takes some time until a taken action by the agent reaches its maximum effect on the environment and consequently the agent receives the reward corresponding to that action by a delay called action-effect delay. Such delays reduce the performance of the learning algorithm and increase the computational costs, as the reinforcement learning agent values the immediate rewards more than the future reward that is more related to the taken action. This paper addresses this issue by introducing an applicable enhanced Q-learning method in which at the beginning of the learning phase, the agent takes a single action and builds a function that reflects the environment‚Äôs response to that action, called the reflexive Œ≥ùõæ\gamma - function. During the training phase, the agent utilizes the created reflexive Œ≥ùõæ\gamma - function to update the Q-values. We have applied the developed method to a structural control problem in which the goal of the agent is to reduce the vibrations of a building subjected to earthquake excitations with a specified delay. Seismic control problems are considered as a complex task in structural engineering because of the stochastic and unpredictable nature of earthquakes and the complex behavior of the structure. Three scenarios are presented to study the effects of zero, medium, and long action-effect delays and the performance of the Enhanced method is compared to the standard Q-learning method. Both RL methods use a neural network to learn to estimate the state-action value function that is used to control the structure. The results show that the enhanced method significantly outperforms the performance of the original method in all cases, and also improves the stability of the algorithm in dealing with action-effect delays. Keywords Reinforcement learning ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot Neural networks ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot Structural control ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot Earthquake ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot Seismic control ‚ãÖ‚ãÖ\cdot Smart structures

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 51 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 51"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "PEER Ground Motion Database - PEER Center.",
        "Robuste Regelung: Analyse Und Entwurf von Linearen Regelungssystemen Mit Unsicheren Physikalischen Parametern.",
        "Optimal control of adaptive/smart bridge structures.",
        "Multiobjective optimal structural vibration control using fuzzy logic control system.",
        "Multiobjective optimal absorber system for torsionally coupled seismically excited structures.",
        "Multiobjective optimal fuzzy logic controller driven active and hybrid control systems for seismically excited nonlinear buildings.",
        "Traffic signal optimization through discrete and continuous reinforcement learning with robustness analysis in downtown tehran.",
        "Vibration mitigation of nonlinear crane system against earthquake excitations with the self-tuning fuzzy logic PID controller.",
        "Direct velocity feedback control of large space structures.",
        "Neural networks for structural control of a benchmark problem, active tendon system.",
        "Nonlinear Structural Control Using Neural Networks.",
        "Dynamic Programming.",
        "The super-Turing computational power of plastic recurrent neural networks.",
        "Robust H‚àû static output feedback control with actuator saturation.",
        "Multicriteria adaptive differential evolution for global numerical optimization.",
        "A multiwavelet neural network-based response surface method for structural reliability analysis.",
        "LQR Control of Wind Excited Benchmark Building Using Variable Stiffness Tuned Mass Damper.",
        "A programmer‚Äìinterpreter neural network architecture for prefrontal cognitive control.",
        "Modern Control Systems.",
        "State-space solutions to standard H/sub 2/and H/sub infinity/control problems.",
        "Feedback Control of Dynamic Systems, volume 3.",
        "Active control of structures using neural networks.",
        "Active mass driver system as the first application of active structural control.",
        "Intelligent Control Systems Using Soft Computing Methodologies.",
        "Neuro-fuzzy and soft computing-a computational approach to learning and machine intelligence [Book Review].",
        "Ant colony optimization algorithm based PID controller for LFC of single area power system with non-linearity and boiler dynamics.",
        "Design of fuzzy logic controller for smart base isolation system using genetic algorithm.",
        "Reinforcement learning in robotics: A survey.",
        "Combined feedback‚Äìfeedforward control of wind turbines using state-constrained model predictive control.",
        "Linear Optimal Control Systems, volume 1.",
        "Control System Fundamentals.",
        "Reinforcement learning for robots using neural networks.",
        "Vibration control of building structures using self-organizing and self-learning neural networks.",
        "Evolutionary algorithms to discover quantitative association rules.",
        "Model predictive control of structures under earthquakes using acceleration feedback.",
        "Artificial neuron‚Äìglia networks learning approach based on cooperative coevolution.",
        "Human-level control through deep reinforcement learning.",
        "Sliding Mode Control of Cable-Stayed Bridge Subjected to Seismic Excitation.",
        "Autonomous Inverted Helicopter Flight via Reinforcement Learning.",
        "Differential Neural Networks for Robust Nonlinear Control: Identification, State Estimation and Trajectory Tracking.",
        "On the use of fuzzy partitions to protect data.",
        "A framework for brain learning-based control of smart structures.",
        "Performance of a five-storey benchmark model using an active tuned mass damper and a fuzzy controller.",
        "Adaptive fuzzy controller for active tuned mass damper of a benchmark tall building subjected to seismic and wind loads.",
        "Mathematical Control Theory: Deterministic Finite Dimensional Systems, volume 6.",
        "Reinforcement Learning: an Introduction.",
        "TD-Gammon, a self-teaching backgammon program, achieves master-level play.",
        "Algorithms for chattering reduction in system control.",
        "Q-learning.",
        "Reinforcement Learning: State-of-the-Art.",
        "Multiobjective optimization for model selection in kernel methods in regression."
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 51 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Enhancing reinforcement learning by a finite reward response filter with a case study in intelligent structural control, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
